Just adding my ArgoUML document in case we end needing to use any of it
We probably should discuss our submissions for Assign 4 and see what we want to implement in our project.
Where should we start?
probably with the customer
what fields do we feel are essential
and what do we feel are "nice to have"
and what are extraneous.
by fields you mean attributes Tony?
So first, should we look at it as a Customer or a CustomerAccount or a VIPCustomer or VIPAccount?
yah.
This whole system is for VIP customers and the owner, so i would say VIPCustomer?
My only concern with that is that we have to keep track of points until they become VIP
so do we want a VIPCustomer class that extends Customer?
or is it enough to have a boolean attribute?
The boolean attribute should be enough (in my case, I switched it from a boolean to a calculated method since really that value depends on the purchases)
(though you could potentially cache the value after calculating it once inside of the customer as a boolean)
i agree it should be a calculated method, even though I originally put it as two boolean variables (isTempGold and isPermGold)
maybe a boolean for PermGold?
@TonyPotter Overall though, I think your Customer class is pretty darn close to how it probably should look since you included a lot of the extra methods that we would probably need to add
so then what attributes are essential and what is "nice to have"?
cardNumber, clearly, and Name
though I think just having a simple isGold() method should suffice (since there really isn't a difference between a temporary gold person and a permanent gold person...they're both "GOLD")
a decision on the name would be to break it down into first/last name
I decided to go ahead and do that for mine since I know with databases it can be quite handy to have that breakdown down the road
only reason I thought a isPermGold as an attribute was to check first, almost as a short circuit in the isGold() method.
i agree isTempGold is useless.

i gotcha on the short circuit (that would be the cached value you would update after isGold() is run for the first time correct? So initially it's false and the isGold() body runs and at the end it updates the internal attribute...then for subsequent calls it can just short circuit and return that value correct?)
right.
so if (isPermGold) return true;
then //test last 30 days.
so phone and address - essential or nice to have?
Address was not part of the original requirements IIRC?
but I think it's a nice to have
I would leave it
leave it in?
phone number was part of the original requirements so we should keep that as well
ok, so we'll need an Address class to implement?
store phone as a long or as fields (area code/prefix/number?)
yup, unless there's something already built-in to java that handles that (addresses)
I think a long would be easier to work with, but breaking it down could be useful...let me take a quick look at something (to help decide on the area code breakdown yay/nay)
I vote on skipping address class - does not help any other requirement either.
like mailing vip status etc.
right Murali, address is nice to have.
not essential
maybe implement in a later stage.
not a big deal to implement...we will add it at the end.
so purchases, I implemented as a List of type Purchase
and for accessors I had getPurchases() returning a List
getPointsLast30Days and getPointsLIfetime() returning ints
and addPurchase(Purchase) which adds to the list.
what do you think?

@TonyPotter for the phone numbers question, I would break out the area code separate from the rest (ideally), so you'd end up with two fields making up the phone number, but leaving it all as one field is perfectly ok as well.
looking at your uml...
As an extra functionality we can also add the points received in each purchase?
@OmarRamos  so you want a long phonenumber that we could mask to format or divide by 10000000 to get area code?
Purchase as list might become a large object over 30 days...hey are we jumping into coding...
I think that looks good (I think I did mine somewhat similarly)
we're just discussing architecture
good...
implementation comes much later.  we're basically coming up with a combined Assignment 4 :)
we're "prototyping" our methods :)
As an aside, I'm guessing for data storage we're going to be using some sort of SQLite database
yeah...prototyping...
Omar, storage is something we can decide later.
@TonyPotter I think that approach for the phone number should work :-)
only reason I wanted a List of all purchases was to easily access the last 30 days.  We could keep a running total of lifetime points in a attribute
30 day purchase list is not a requirement...right...a running total will be more effecient
issue is how do we keep track of expiring points leaving the 30 day window?
i see your point...

Since I was looking at things from a database perspective, I knew the total points could be easily calculated at that level and simply returned via a method we create pretty quickly (without having to store too much data within the object...just the numeric results).
Same goes for the 30 day window bit (with a database query)
ok, then just accessors but no record in the object.  all db calls, right?
or actually
if its all in db, we don't really care how many points they have at one time
just if they're gold right now, whether temp or perm.
I would say it's ok to leave the record of the object in for now, but we may end up removing it by the end depending on how it ends up fleshing out
which is a db call.
yup that sounds about right
so should getPhoneNumber() return String or long?
string
In the example the professor used as String
I know the instructor used a string in an example, but I think long is probably a bit better (so long as we assume we're stripping out any non-numeric characters on save)
PEnnsylvania 6-5000 :)
string is just easier to work with I think if we're not thinking of "normalizing" all of the input
we could have getPhoneNumber() and getFormattedPhoneNumber()
I think that'll work nicely
we are getting ahead...of our current phase...

OK, going back to the Deliverables list:

- Initial use-case model 
- Initial risk assessment (Chandra)
- Project plan, showing phases and iterations (Tony...not sure if this one or the use case model fell under "architecture"?)
- [Optionally] One or more prototypes (Murali)

It sounded like for this week it should be relatively light weight
and be concerned with the main "actors" and how they would be using the application

if we're implementing beta release in Deliverable 3, we're almost done with it by then.

Before we part ways, i have some questions as a risk assesement, let me what you guys think
Thu will work.

Risk Assessment:
1. Can the hardware or software chosen to do the project handle the workload required to complete the project? Is the development platform suitable?

2. Is the cost of labor, support costs and other charges within the budget and will it increase year to year?

3. Do we have enough resources / manpower and will the project team member be in place when required?

4. Has the requirements been gathered and defined adequetly?

5. Is the requirements continually changing?

6. Will the project be completed on time?

7. Do we have the correct platform for testing and modeling?

8. Will the system require continuos maintenance and debugging?

9. Has the project been planned carefully and do we have a vision document?

10. Do we have experienced team members and has the work been divided correctly?

11. Is the user interface correct, clear and easy to use?
